article_title: Most San Antonio hospitals better than average on Medicare measure
article_text:
Most San Antonio hospitals better than average on Medicare measure

Photo: Express-News File Photo University Health System includes University Hospital, one of two...

Some San Antonio hospitals will see their Medicare payments cut once again in the new fiscal year starting Oct. 1 because the federal government concluded they had excessive readmissions of Medicare patients.

article_metadata.description: Some San Antonio hospitals will see their Medicare payments cut once again in the new fiscal year starting Oct. 1 because the federal government concluded they had excessive readmissions of Medicare patients.  The program, established by the Affordable Care Act, reduces Medicare payments to hospitals found to have excessive readmissions of Medicare patients originally hospitalized for heart attacks, heart failure, pneumonia, chronic lung problems and hip or knee replacements.  Baptist Health System said it launched a transitional care management department this year to better help patients and their caregivers after release, according to Dr. Dana Kellis, chief medical officer.  Southwest General Hospital is attacking the issue in two ways — by recruiting more primary care physicians to the South Side and better engaging patients and their families to make sure they fully understand discharge instructions, CEO P. Craig Desmond said.  “Through expanded access to primary health care services, the residents in South San Antonio will be better equipped to manage chronic conditions in the outpatient setting,” Desmond said in a prepared statement.  Patients will be contacted after their release to make sure they followed up with a primary care physician and are taking prescribed medications, Desmond said.  The 0.01 percent fine is less severe than the penalties imposed on other public hospitals in Texas, such as Harris Health System in Houston, University Medical Center of El Paso and Dallas’ Parkland Health and Hospital System.  University Health also uses predictive analytical software in its electronic medical records to identify patients likely to be readmitted so case managers can take a different approach if needed.  Local hospitals not penalized in the coming fiscal year include Christus Santa Rosa Health System, Nix Health Care System, Foundation Surgical Hospital of San Antonio, Victory Medical Center and South Texas Spine & Surgical Hospital.
